text: Family Member: You’re talking about placebo? Doctor: Yeah. So there is a two out of three chance that you will have a chance to get that medication. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: If, if I need that medication, I could though? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Can I go to England and get it? Doctor: Or one of those countries. I think Germany or England, yes, one of the European countries. Patient: I could go over there and do it. How long do they treat you, though, for that? Doctor: It’s about four doses, a total of four doses every six weeks or something. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: So it’s not, uh, it’s not a one-time deal. Family Member: Wow.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: And, then, you could move into that study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you are AR-V7 negative and, uh, phase one study is of more interest to you, we can say, “Okay, you’re gonna stop as of this date the, the current study.” Patient: Right-- the drugs Doctor: And then we could reserve the slot for the new trial. Patient: Okay. Okay. That works. Doctor: Questions? Family Member: I do, I think that, uh, one of the, I guess, questions that came up in my mind was the signs of the cancer development in the adrenal is it consistent that it would be prostate cancer or we just don’t even know Doctor: Yeah. I mean, the assumption is that it is prostate cancer. Why give him a second cancer? Uh. So, that’s the assumption. You know, the adrenal gland can have benign tumors in it. Okay? Um. You know, if prostate cancer went in there, that would be a possible reason why it would bleed. Um. Sometimes the adrenal gland just doesn’t get a good blood supply, and it does bleed. Or, if you’re under stress, or like today with your blood pressure shooting through the roof, but your scans were yesterday. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh. It’s pretty nonspecific. Your aspirin puts you at a higher risk for like various

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: I might need pictures if we can’t your catheter is out. So what’s the problem there? Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So most of that really is just plumbing. Family Member: Right. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that the tube itself is going to make a channel that has to be in the six-week time so that the channel can sort of get wide enough so that pee comes out, okay. And that’s why they are worried about shall we take it out, shall we not take it out, you should have left it in. And if it’s obstructed it’s got to come out or your kidney function gets bad again. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And that’s why they’re saying it needs to be changed every four to six weeks so that it doesn’t get blocked. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so now the issue is they’re going to probably be doing a lot of voiding trials to see whether or not you can pee on your own. You know do they clamp it and you feel like okay I’ve got to pee and then you can sort of see if you can get it out. So that’s what the urologists are going to be doing.

text: Patient: I’ve been praying that… Doctor: We removed it and the fact that we removed it may minimize the reoccurrence. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: So we’ll see. Patient: Um hmm. Well that’s why I want to go that route you know. Doctor: Yeah and you did the right thing. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Because if you had uh advanced disease it’s better to take it out first and then give radiation therapy as opposed to getting radiation therapy and then doing surgery. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The surgery is much more difficult, the side effects are more prevalent - Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - in patients who’ve had radiation therapy followed by surgery.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
